contentrichtext.text: {{Other people2|Harlan (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Harlan Richard 1796-1843.png|thumb|200px|Richard Harlan.]] '''Richard Harlan''' (September 19, 1796 – September 30, 1843) was an [[United States|American]] [[natural history|naturalist]], [[zoologist]], [[Herpetology|herpetologist]], [[physicist]], and [[paleontologist]]. He was the author of [http://resource.nlm.nih.gov/60930050R ''Fauna Americana'' (1825)] and ''American Herpetology''.<ref name="Kelly1920">{{cite book|author=Howard Atwood Kelly|title=A Cyclopedia of American Medical Biography: Comprising the Lives of Eminent Deceased Physicians and Surgeons from 1610 to 1910|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=GPssAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=6 May 2012|year=1920|publisher=W.B. Saunders Company|page=492}}</ref> Harlan was born in [[Philadelphia]], to Joshua Harlan, a wealthy [[Quaker]] merchant, and his wife Sarah, one of their ten children. He was three years older than his brother [[Josiah Harlan]], who would become the first American to visit [[Afghanistan]] and who was the presumed inspiration for [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s story [[The Man Who Would Be King]]. He graduated in [[medicine]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] taking time off during his studies to spend a year at sea as a [[ship's surgeon]] for the [[British East India Company]]. In 1821 he was elected professor of [[comparative anatomy]] in the Philadelphia museum. One of his passions was the collection and study of human skulls. At its peak, his collection contained 275 skulls, the largest such collection in America.<ref name="MacIntyre2004">{{cite book|author=[[Ben MacIntyre]]|title=The Man Who Would Be King: The First American in Afghanistan|year=2004|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux}}</ref> He died of apoplexy in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]].<ref name="Kelly1920"/> ==See also== *[[Harlan's muskox]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=27850056}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Harlan, Richard | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = September 19, 1796 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Philadelphia, Pennsylvania | DATE OF DEATH = September 30, 1843 | PLACE OF DEATH = New Orleans, Louisiana }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harlan, Richard}} [[Category:American mammalogists]] [[Category:American herpetologists]] [[Category:Corresponding Members of the St Petersburg Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:1796 births]] [[Category:1843 deaths]] {{US-zoologist-stub}}
